result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Chad E Phillips

records.addlTxt:
When there is a date w/ a bed available, the bond can be modified on the day he would leave for treatment, go straight to treatment, complete it, and then be returned back to the jail and bond will be reviewed again. The day the program ends, is that day the defendant needs to be back in the jail.
Absolute sobriety, Do not enter any establishment whose primary purpose is to sell or serve alcohol.

10:09 AM Defendant Chad E Phillips appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Travis S Slattery appeared by phone for Chad E Phillips.  Prosecuting attorney Jennifer C Zima in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
Not guilty pleas entered.

When there is a date w/ a bed available, the bond can be modified on the day he would leave for treatment, go straight to treatment, complete it, and then be returned back to the jail and bond will be reviewed again. The day the program ends, is that day the defendant needs to be back in the jail.
Absolute sobriety, Do not enter any establishment whose primary purpose is to sell or serve alcohol.

10:02 AM Defendant Chad E Phillips appeared by video, in custody in the Waupaca County Jail.  Attorney Travis S Slattery appeared by phone for Chad E Phillips.  Prosecuting attorney Jennifer C Zima in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
Court finds probable cause to continue this matter. Not guilty pleas are entered.
Attorney Slattery gives an argument for a bond modification.
Final pre-trial scheduled for December 20, 2022 at 11:00 am.
Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Defendant
records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Defendant

records.addlTxt:
11:28 AM Defendant Chad E Phillips appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Travis S Slattery in court for Chad E Phillips.  Prosecuting attorney David R. Knaapen in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
Officer Berg is sworn in and testifies. Testifies to being a Police Officer and K-9 Handler with the Nekoosa Police Department. Testifies to doing a registration check that lead to the traffic stop. Testifies to the license plate being registered to a different vehicle than what it was on. Testifies to the defendant being the driver. Witness identifies the defendant in court, court recognizes. Testifies to an odor of intoxicants coming from the vehicle and conducting field sobriety tests on the defendant. Testifies to the defendant taking a PBT. Testifies to the defendant having 5 prior OWI convictions. Testifies to his alcohol restriction. Testifies to a blood draw being done but waiting on the blood draw results.
Attorney Slattery cross examines the witness. Witness testifies to the clues observed on the field sobriety tests.

Court finds probable cause to believe a felony was committed and the defendant committed it.
Bond is continued.
Arraignment scheduled for October 17, 2022 at 10:00 am.
Absolute sobriety, Do not enter any establishment whose primary purpose is to sell or serve alcohol. $5000
Preliminary hearing and Arraignment on September 26, 2022 at 11:30 am.
Absolute sobriety, do not enter any establishments that sell or serve alcohol.

1:52 PM Defendant Chad E Phillips appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney David R. Knaapen in court for State of Wisconsin.   State request bond continue.  Defendant argues for bond modification.  Court modifies bond modification.
Absolute sobriety. Do not enter any establishment whose primary purpose is to sell or serve alcohol. 22-1983 $10,000
Absolute sobriety, do not enter any establishments that sell or serve alcohol.
